		function addLoadEvent(func) {
			var oldonload = window.onload;
			if (typeof window.onload != 'function') {
				window.onload = func;
			} else {
				window.onload = function () {
					oldonload();
					func();
				}
			}

				var linkElements = [
					'a[href="https://wordpress.com/?ref=footer_blog"]',
					'a[href="https://wordpress.com/?ref=footer_website"]',
					'a[href="https://wordpress.com/?ref=vertical_footer"]',

					return false;

<article id="post-9876" class="post-9876 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-my-musings category-various-things tag-age-of-assassins tag-anna-smith-spark tag-anthony-ryan tag-blog tag-blogger tag-blogging tag-blood-of-assassins tag-blood-song tag-book-blog tag-book-blogger tag-book-review-blog tag-book-review-blogger tag-books tag-dead-mans-steel tag-empires-of-dust tag-epic tag-fantasy tag-fantasy-book-blog tag-fantasy-book-blogger tag-fantasy-list tag-fantasy-series tag-fantasy-trilogies tag-finished-fantasy-trilogies tag-grimdark tag-john-gwynne tag-king-of-assassins tag-lord-of-the-rings tag-luke-scull tag-mark-lawrence tag-of-blood-and-bone tag-of-blood-and-bone-trilogy tag-orbit tag-ravens-shadow tag-red-queens-war tag-rj-barker tag-robin-hobb tag-sword-of-the-north tag-the-broken-empire-trilogy tag-the-court-of-broken-knives tag-the-farseer-trilogy tag-the-first-law-trilogy tag-the-grim-company tag-the-house-of-sacrifice tag-the-live-ship-traders-trilogy tag-the-tawny-man-trilogy tag-the-tower-of-living-and-dying tag-the-wounded-kingdom tag-the-wounded-kingdom-trilogy tag-top-list tag-top-ten tag-top-ten-fantasy-list tag-traditional tag-trilogies tag-trilogy tag-wordpress">
	<header class="entry-header">

		
		<span class="cat-links"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/category/my-musings/" rel="category tag">My Musings</a> &middot; <a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/category/various-things/" rel="category tag">Various Things</a></span>
		<h1 class="entry-title">Top Finished Fantasy Trilogies you should&nbsp;read.</h1>
		<div class="entry-meta">
			<span class="posted-on"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/" rel="bookmark"><time class="entry-date published" datetime="2018-08-06T12:00:07+01:00">Aug 6, 2018</time><time class="updated" datetime="2020-05-08T13:56:19+01:00">May 8, 2020</time></a></span><span class="byline"> <span class="author vcard"><a class="url fn n" href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/author/thetattooedbookgeek/">Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek</a></span></span>		</div>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content">
		<p style="text-align:center;"><img data-attachment-id="34765" data-permalink="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/fant/" data-orig-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png" data-orig-size="450,300" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="fant" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png?w=300" data-large-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png?w=450" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-34765" src="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png?w=663" alt="fant"   srcset="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png 450w, https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png?w=150&amp;h=100 150w, https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fant.png?w=300&amp;h=200 300w" sizes="(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px" /></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Well, the title of the post is itself quite explanatory, I&#8217;m going to list <strong>the top finished fantasy trilogies</strong> that I have read and that I think every fantasy fan should read and if you&#8217;re not a fantasy fan &#8220;<em>shudders, tuts and then shakes head</em>&#8221; well, you just might find something that piques your interest on the list!</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Obviously, there are many other <strong>fantasy </strong><strong>trilogies</strong> out there and these are only the ones that I have read and that are finished. ðŸ™‚ I also have another post with my <strong>five favourite finished fantasy series</strong> that you can find &#8211; </span><em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2019/01/15/five-favourite-finished-fantasy-series-bookbloggers-bookblogger-bloggers-blogger-fantasy-finishedfantasyseries-fantasyseries-books/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">So, in no particular order:</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The First Law Trilogy by Joe Abercrombie:</span></h4>
<div class="tiled-gallery type-rectangular tiled-gallery-unresized" data-original-width="663" </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Blade Itself </strong>(<em>2006</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Before They Are Hanged </strong>(<em>2007</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Last Argument of Kings </strong>(<em>2008</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Well, we have to start with The First Law trilogy by Lord Grimdark himself Mr Joe Abercrombie. Complex, morally flawed and highly memorable characters, great storytelling, droll and sardonic humour, a gritty and grim world that feels real and lived in, fast-paced and action-packed. This is the quintessential Grimdark trilogy for fans and a must-read! After a long break away from reading The Blade Itself was one of the first grimdark books that I picked up and it, along with the following two books in The First Law trilogy firmly cemented my love for the genre. Even years later, it is a trilogy that I remember, think about and one day wish to re-read to relive the grim splendour found within the pages.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Farseer Trilogy by Robin Hobb:</span></h4>

</div> <!-- close group --> <div class="gallery-group images-1" style="width: 227px; height: 340px;" data-original-width="227" data-original-height="340" > <div class="tiled-gallery-item tiled-gallery-item-small" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"> <a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_/" border="0" itemprop="url"> <meta itemprop="width" content="223"> <meta itemprop="height" content="336"> <img class="" data-attachment-id="33309" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" src="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=223&#038;h=336&#038;ssl=1" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=223&amp;h=336&amp;ssl=1 223w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=99&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 99w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=199&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 199w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51u3zyriuyl-_sx329_bo1204203200_.jpg 331w" width="223" height="336" loading="lazy" data-original-width="223" data-original-height="336" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="51U3zYRIuyL._SX329_BO1,204,203,200_" alt="51U3zYRIuyL._SX329_BO1,204,203,200_" style="width: 223px; height: 336px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Assassin&#8217;s ApprenticeÂ </strong>(<em>1995</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Royal AssassinÂ </strong>(<em>1996</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Assassin&#8217;s QuestÂ </strong>(<em>1997</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Robin Hobb&#8217;s first appearance on my list (<em>not her last as the next two trilogies also come from her</em>). Her Farseer trilogy is a classic and a must-read for every sort of fantasy fan out there. Her world-building and characterisation are top quality with a great main character in FitzChivalry Farseer who narrates the trilogy told in the first person, you are also introduced to Nighteyes one of, if not the best animal companion ever in fantasy, though to just call him a companion is detrimental to his character and role in the story. Then there is the Fool, well, what can you say about the Fool, such an ingenious creation on Hobb&#8217;s part and a wonderful character. A quick mention also to Chade, another top character. And, you also have Regal Farseer, every trilogy/series needs a villain (<em>think Joffrey in Game of Thrones</em>) and Regal is that villain, you will hate him by the end and will be praying that he gets what he so thoroughly deserves. I can&#8217;t praise the first book Assassin&#8217;s Apprentice in this trilogy enough, I&#8217;ve read every other Hobb book because of Fitz&#8217;s first book with the exception of her Soldier Son trilogy. Classic fantasy for everyone, great story, great characters and a unique world in the Six Duchies, a masterpiece!</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Liveship Traders Trilogy by Robin Hobb:</span></h4>

</div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Ship of MagicÂ </strong>(<em>1998</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Mad ShipÂ </strong>(<em>1999</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Ship of Destiny </strong>(<em>2000</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Hobb&#8217;s second trilogy on my list, set after the events of The Farseer trilogy but in a completely different area of The Six Duchies (huge world). This is a trilogy about talking ships or as they are called Live Ships! Yes, I&#8217;m sure there are some of you out there snickering and guffawing at the thought of sentient talking ships and I fully admit that I was one of you. After finishing The Farseer trilogy (<em>I read all three trilogies straight after each other</em>) I had every intention of missing this one out and jumping straight into The Tawny Man trilogy to get back to Fitz&#8217;s story, however someone I know had been reading Hobb to and they told me that this series was worth a look. Well, they were right! While completely different to both The Farseer trilogy (<em>set before</em>) and The Tawny Man trilogy (<em>set after</em>) this is a stunning read. Hobb again manages to create another completely different set of characters with another great story and for those who have read The Farseer trilogy before, well you will get more out of this trilogy with a certain character and that&#8217;s all I&#8217;m saying! ðŸ™‚ And if the idea of talking ships seems odd to you, from someone who felt the same, give it a go, you won&#8217;t regret it and yes, Hobb makes you care about the ships, I know, you find yourself caring for the fates of ships, crazy right! ðŸ™‚</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Tawny Man Trilogy by Robin Hobb:</span></h4>

data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" src="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/61h3ealsfql-_sx331_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=221&#038;h=332&#038;ssl=1" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/61h3ealsfql-_sx331_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=221&amp;h=331&amp;ssl=1 221w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/61h3ealsfql-_sx331_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=100&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 100w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/61h3ealsfql-_sx331_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=200&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 200w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/61h3ealsfql-_sx331_bo1204203200_.jpg 333w" width="221" height="332" loading="lazy" data-original-width="221" data-original-height="332" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="61h3eaLsfqL._SX331_BO1,204,203,200_" alt="61h3eaLsfqL._SX331_BO1,204,203,200_" style="width: 221px; height: 332px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Fool&#8217;s ErrandÂ </strong>(<em>2001</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Golden FoolÂ </strong>(<em>2002</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Fool&#8217;s Fate </strong>(<em>2003</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">OK, this is the last time that Hobb appears on my list, so relax, the Hobb lovefest is over, though if you have ever read any of her books you will see why I rate her work so highly! The Tawny Man trilogy takes place fifteen years after the end of The Farseer trilogy and we are once again reunited with our old friends, Fitz, Fool/Lord Golden (<em>I wonder what he was up to during the gap between trilogies</em>), Chade, Nighteyes and many more. This is a great continuation of the characters stories and Hobb again writes a gripping trilogy that pulls you in whittling away hours as you become engrossed in her world, For me, Fool&#8217;s Errand has one of the most poignant, sad and heartbreaking scene/section in literature, not just in fantasy but in all genres of book. And, I tell you now blog followers, she even managed to evoke emotion in me, making this often sarcastic tattooed male shed a manly tear! Another must-read by one of the greats in fantasy Robin Hobb.</span></p>

<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Prince of ThornsÂ </strong>(<em>2011</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>King of ThornsÂ </strong>(<em>2012</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Emperor of ThornsÂ </strong>(<em>2013</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Can I just write Jorg Ancrath and leave it at that?!?!?!? No, you say, fair enough, here is my quick overview of this trilogy <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2016/03/05/the-broken-empire-trilogy-review/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em> Love this series, pure Grimdark with a dark and psychotic main character in Jorg who won&#8217;t be to everyone&#8217;s taste but&#8230;..if you allow him, then the murdering little blood spilling psychopathic degenerate will captivate you and you find yourself pulled into his story.</span></p>

https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/513ouovluml.jpg?w=196&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 196w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/513ouovluml.jpg 327w" width="218" height="334" loading="lazy" data-original-width="218" data-original-height="334" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="513OUovluML" alt="513OUovluML" style="width: 218px; height: 334px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Prince of FoolsÂ </strong>(<em>2014</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Liar&#8217;s KeyÂ </strong>(<em>2015</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Wheel of OsheimÂ </strong>(<em>2016</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">After I started reading again and got into fantasy Mark Lawrence&#8217;s Broken Empire trilogy was one of my favourite trilogies out there and I loved Jorg Ancrath, he was so different to any character that I had read before. And, so it pains me to write it but overall I prefer his second trilogy with The Red Queen&#8217;s War, again set in his Broken Empire world, the story takes place during the same time frame as The Broken Empire and you may even see a little appearance by everyone&#8217;s favourite little psychopath Jorg in the books to. Focusing on two main characters Jalan Kendeth and Snorri ver Snagason, Jalan is a coward and a womaniser while Snorri is his complete opposite, honourable and courageous, Snorri will face danger head-on with a smile and Jalan will run away whilst screaming like a girl. The story throughout the three books in the trilogy is great and the banter and interplay between the two leads is top quality, emotion and humour of the highest level. Both Jalan and Snorri grow so much during the trilogy, that at the end, yes, they are both still recognisable as the characters you met pages ago at the beginning of Prince of Fools (<em>Book 1</em>) but they have developed so much and traits from each other have rubbed off on them both, Snorri is still Snorri but Jalan by the end has some redeeming qualities about him to. The trilogies end is also just pure Jalan and you have to smile. This is more accessible then Lawrence&#8217;s Broken Empire trilogy and is a must-read for fantasy fans with a captivating duo of great lead characters.</span></p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">A review of The Liar&#8217;s Key (<em>book 2</em>) can be found <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2016/03/23/the-liars-key-book-review/">!!HERE!! </a></strong></em>And, a review for the final book The Wheel of Osheim can be found<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2016/05/17/the-wheel-of-osheim-book-review/"> <em><strong>!!HERE!!</strong></em></a></span></p>

<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Herald of the StormÂ </strong>(<em>2013</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Shattered CrownÂ </strong>(<em>2014</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Lord of Ashes </strong>(<em>2015</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Another top quality Grimdark trilogy here, that I personally feel is an underrated gem of a trilogy. I don&#8217;t see it around much on many fantasy lists, so it&#8217;s getting a place on mine! A dark, well-paced, well written engaging trilogy with a decent cast of characters who pull you into their city and their story. A far more detailed overview of the trilogy can be found in my review <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2016/03/15/steelhaven-trilogy-review/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></span></p>

<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Emperor&#8217;s BladesÂ </strong>(<em>2014</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Providence of FireÂ </strong>(<em>2015</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Last Mortal BondÂ </strong>(<em>2016</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">A fast-paced well-written trilogy revolving around three main characters (<em>siblings</em>) and their subsequent story arc&#8217;s. Monks, Politicians and a crack commando unit &#8211; yay for an A-Team reference in a fantasy list! ðŸ™‚ Great character development throughout from a trio of really interesting main sibling characters, set in a richly detailed world, action-packed, anyone who&#8217;s read this will agree, who doesn&#8217;t want to be a Ketteral?? Â It really has all you could want in a fantasy trilogy.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">Raven&#8217;s Shadow Trilogy by Anthony Ryan:</span></h4>
<div class="tiled-gallery type-rectangular tiled-gallery-unresized" data-original-width="663" style="width: 221px; height: 336px;" data-original-width="221" data-original-height="336" > <div class="tiled-gallery-item tiled-gallery-item-small" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"> <a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/51refw-2yl/" border="0" itemprop="url"> <meta itemprop="width" content="217"> <meta itemprop="height" content="332"> <img class="" data-attachment-id="33329" data-orig-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51refw-2yl.jpg" data-orig-size="327,500" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="51+REfw-2YL" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51refw-2yl.jpg?w=196" data-large-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51refw-2yl.jpg?w=327" https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51refw-2yl.jpg 327w" width="217" height="332" loading="lazy" data-original-width="217" data-original-height="332" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="51+REfw-2YL" alt="51+REfw-2YL" style="width: 217px; height: 332px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Blood SongÂ </strong>(<em>2011</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Tower LordÂ </strong>(<em>2014</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Queen of FireÂ </strong>(<em>2015</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">This was a hard one as to whether to even include it on the list or not as I&#8217;m a massive fan of the first book but felt that the second book was a disappointment with the third and final book going some way to rectifying my misgivings about the second book. The first book is written in the same vein as Patrick Rothfuss and his Kingkiller Chronicles, where the main character Vaelin Al Sorna recounts his tale to another. However, by the end of the book, this has changed as Vaelin&#8217;s tale reaches the present and we go from him recounting his past story to what is currently happening. I fully admit that when I started the series I thought great, it sounds really good and Blood Song is an amazing book, great characters, friendships and detailed world-building all created a complex story but&#8230;..</span></p>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">When I started the first book I thought that I was going to be reading another KingKiller Chronicles and following Vaelin through his story for the three books or at least up until about halfway through the third book but that wasn&#8217;t the case. In the sequels Vaelin doesn&#8217;t play as large of a role in the two books and we go from having one main character point of view to multiple points of view and as you can see, the third book is called Queen of Fire, Vaelin is a fella, he would-be a King so it&#8217;s obvious that he isn&#8217;t the main character in the story. I&#8217;ve added the trilogy to the list as I believe Blood Song is a great book and a must-read for fantasy fans and on a whole, the trilogy is a decent read. It&#8217;s just a shame that Ryan set such a high standard with the first book and then failed to match it with the two sequels.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Lord of The Rings by J.R.R. Tolkien:</span></h4>

<ol>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Fellowship of the RingÂ </strong>(<em>1954</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Two TowersÂ </strong>(<em>1954</em>).</span></li>
<li style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Return of the KingÂ </strong>(<em>1955</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p style="text-align:left;"><span style="color:#000000;">Well, it&#8217;s the Granddaddy of all fantasy trilogies!!!! The old-timer that is The Lord of The Rings. If you haven&#8217;t read the books then I am guessing that you will at least have watched the films, so it&#8217;s a name that you all should be well aware of! Anyone out there not heard of The Lord of The Rings?? Hands in the air?? Nope, didn&#8217;t think so! Good! It&#8217;s a literary classic and a trilogy everyone should read!</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Grim Company by Luke Scull:</span></h4>

https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51kh8ntmbrl-_sx324_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=98&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 98w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51kh8ntmbrl-_sx324_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=196&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 196w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/51kh8ntmbrl-_sx324_bo1204203200_.jpg 326w" width="219" height="336" loading="lazy" data-original-width="219" data-original-height="336" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="51KH8nTmbRL._SX324_BO1,204,203,200_" alt="51KH8nTmbRL._SX324_BO1,204,203,200_" style="width: 219px; height: 336px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> <div class="gallery-group images-1" style="width: 217px; height: 340px;" data-original-width="217" data-original-height="340" > <div class="tiled-gallery-item tiled-gallery-item-small" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"> <a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_/" border="0" itemprop="url"> <meta itemprop="width" content="213"> <meta itemprop="height" content="336"> <img class="" data-attachment-id="33301" data-orig-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg" data-orig-size="317,499" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="5129hDWI0LL._SX315_BO1,204,203,200_" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=191" data-large-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=317" src="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=213&#038;h=336&#038;ssl=1" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=213&amp;h=335&amp;ssl=1 213w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=95&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 95w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=191&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 191w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/5129hdwi0ll-_sx315_bo1204203200_.jpg 317w" width="213" height="336" loading="lazy" data-original-width="213" data-original-height="336" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="5129hDWI0LL._SX315_BO1,204,203,200_" alt="5129hDWI0LL._SX315_BO1,204,203,200_" style="width: 213px; height: 336px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Grim CompanyÂ </strong>(<em>2013</em>).</span></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Sword Of The NorthÂ </strong>(<em>2014</em>).</span></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Dead Man&#8217;s SteelÂ </strong>(<em>2016</em>).</span></li>
</ol>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Grim Company trilogy features an eclectic mix of characters you grow to care about throughout the course of the three books, an interesting and gritty setting, an entertaining story with twists and turns, emotion, dark humour and in addition to those, one of my favourite staples of the most wonderful genre that is grimdark, plentiful amounts of bloodthirsty and limb severing visceral action.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Iâ€™m a big fan of the old and grizzled duo of the legendary highland warrior Brodar Kayne and Jerek the Wolf who are two of my favourite characters. Brodar Kayne, once known as â€˜<em>the Sword of the North</em>â€˜ was the greatest swordsman in the North but age and time have caught up with him though he is still a formidable adversary and highly skilled with a blade. He is more calm and measured and someone who offers words of wisdom. While Jerek is angry, blunt, coarse and foul-mouthed with a gruff, surly and bad-tempered countenance. He is someone whose demeanour belies the depth to him as a character. Jerek often has many fucks to give and they are usually accompanied by the bloody blades of his twin axes.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">It firmly stands on its own but if you are a fan of the works of Abercrombie then you&#8217;ll enjoy The Grim Company.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">The Wounded Kingdom by RJ Barker.</span></h4>

https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/514vruaeehl-_sx316_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=96&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 96w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/514vruaeehl-_sx316_bo1204203200_.jpg?w=191&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 191w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/514vruaeehl-_sx316_bo1204203200_.jpg 318w" width="217" height="341" loading="lazy" data-original-width="217" data-original-height="341" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="514vRUaeEHL._SX316_BO1,204,203,200_" alt="514vRUaeEHL._SX316_BO1,204,203,200_" style="width: 217px; height: 341px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Age of Assassins</strong> (<em>2017</em>) &#8211; find my review</span><em><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2017/08/03/age-of-assassins-by-r-j-barker-book-review/"><strong> !!HERE!!</strong></a></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Blood of Assassins </strong>(<em>2018</em>) &#8211; find my review</span><em><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/02/22/blood-of-assassins-the-wounded-kingdom-book-2-by-r-j-barker-bookreview-bookbloggers-bookblogger-review/"><strong> !!HERE!!</strong></a></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>King of Assassins </strong>(<em>2018</em>) &#8211; find my review</span> <em><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/02/king-of-assassins-the-wounded-kingdom-3-by-rj-barker-book-review/"><strong>!!HERE!!</strong></a></em></li>
</ol>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Wounded Kingdom is set in the Tired Lands and told in the first-person perspective and narrated by the assassin Girton Club-Foot.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">A span of years separates each book. At the beginning of Age of Assassins Girton is a fifteen-year-old and all the trials and tribulations that are associated with coming-of-age and when we get to King of Assassins the concluding volume of the trilogy Girton is thirty-five years of age and world-weary. Time, events and life change him over the course of the trilogy but even with those changes he is still recognisable as the Girton from the beginning and he is a character that you can really get behind, care about and root for.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Though The Wounded Kingdom is very much Girton&#8217;s story there are many fantastic other characters included too. To name a few, Girton&#8217;s master, Merela Karn (<em>they are far more than just master and apprentice, they have such a strong and emotional bond and the relationship between them is a highlight of the entire trilogy</em>), Aydor (<em>who goes through a drastic change during the trilogy and turned into one of my favourite characters</em>), Rufra, Nywulf and even Xus, Girton&#8217;s Mount, C&#8217;mon, you all know you love animal companions in books!</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Barker doesn&#8217;t bog you down with excessive detail but with each book more is revealed and the world-building in The Wounded Kingdom is fascinating with an intriguing magic system that is well incorporated into both the story and the world.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">There&#8217;s plenty of action in the trilogy (<em>a couple of large battles, one in the second book, Blood of Assassins is phenomenal and another highlight of the trilogy but most of the action is small-scale battles and duels involving Girton which often have a beauty and a poetry to them as Girton dances going through a series of iterations when he fights</em>) but it&#8217;s not the main focus and whilst there is plenty to satisfy any cravings that you might have what action there is, is included alongside character development, intrigue and storytelling to create an absorbing read for each book in the trilogy.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Wounded Kingdom has a thriller element running through it with each book having mysteries that require solving by Girton and in my review of King of Assassins, I dubbed it as &#8216;<em>thrilling fantasy</em>&#8216; as it&#8217;s a perfect blending together of the two genres.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Near the end of King of Assassins, the last book in the trilogy you still don&#8217;t know how Barker will conclude his trilogy and with a low page count left the story could still go in any number of different directions. Yet still, Barker manages to knock you for six ending with a shocking revelation that will make you sit back and reflect on many events that happened over all three of the books and it is a perfect conclusion, thought-provoking and surprising with a poignant epilogue too. </span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">With each book Barker upped the ante and improved, Age of Assassins was a great debut, Blood of Assassins was a better book and then King of Assassins was even better, the best of the three and nigh on perfection.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Wounded Kingdom trilogy is a journey that is well worth your time and Girton is a character that you will love.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">Empires of Dust by Anna Smith Spark.</span></h4>

https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod2.jpg?w=103&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 103w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod2.jpg?w=206&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 206w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod2.jpg 344w" width="217" height="316" loading="lazy" data-original-width="217" data-original-height="316" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="eod2" alt="eod2" style="width: 217px; height: 316px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> <div class="gallery-group images-1" style="width: 220px; height: 320px;" data-original-width="220" data-original-height="320" > <div class="tiled-gallery-item tiled-gallery-item-small" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"> <a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/eod3/" border="0" itemprop="url"> <meta itemprop="width" content="216"> <meta itemprop="height" content="316"> <img class="" data-attachment-id="37999" data-orig-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg" data-orig-size="342,500" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{&quot;aperture&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;credit&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;camera&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;caption&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;created_timestamp&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;copyright&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;focal_length&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;iso&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;shutter_speed&quot;:&quot;0&quot;,&quot;title&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;orientation&quot;:&quot;0&quot;}" data-image-title="eod3" data-image-description="" data-medium-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=205" data-large-file="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=342" src="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=216&#038;h=316&#038;ssl=1" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=216&amp;h=316&amp;ssl=1 216w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=103&amp;h=150&amp;ssl=1 103w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg?w=205&amp;h=300&amp;ssl=1 205w, https://i0.wp.com/thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/eod3.jpg 342w" width="216" height="316" loading="lazy" data-original-width="216" data-original-height="316" itemprop="http://schema.org/image" title="eod3" alt="eod3" style="width: 216px; height: 316px;" /> </a> </div> </div> <!-- close group --> </div> <!-- close row --> </div>
<ol>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Court of Broken KnivesÂ </strong>(<em>2017</em>) &#8211; find my review</span> <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2017/10/21/the-court-of-broken-knives-by-anna-smith-spark-mini-book-review/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The Tower of Living and DyingÂ </strong>(<em>2018</em>) &#8211; find my review</span> <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2019/04/11/the-tower-of-living-and-dying-empires-of-dust-2-by-anna-smith-spark-book-review-bookblogger-bookbloggers-bookreview-grimdark-thetoweroflivinganddying-queenofgrimdark-harpervoyageruk/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>The House of SacrificeÂ </strong>(<em>2019</em>) &#8211; find my review</span> <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2019/08/22/the-house-of-sacrifice-empires-of-dust-3-by-anna-smith-spark-book-review-bookblogger-bookbloggers-bookreview-empiresofdust-thehouseofsacrifice-queenofgrimdark/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></li>
</ol>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Throughout the Empires of Dust trilogy, you follow Marith Altrersyr, King Ruin, King Death and Amrath Returned on his journey, his merry dance of conquest, death, destruction and massacre across Irlast. From a nobody in a mercenary crew marching on Sorlost in The Court of Broken Knives to the King of Irlast in The House of Sacrifice. We see him descend into madness, see him kill, destroy, raze cities to the ground and bathe the world in rivers of blood. His empire is been built from the death, the blood, the bones, the corpses, the decaying remains and the rotting flesh of his enemies, from those who stand against him, turned to dust in the ground.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">As well as following Marith, the story also takes place in Sorlost, the crown jewel of the Sekemleth Empire. Sorlost is like an aged movie star whose beauty has long since faded and whose glory days lay far behind them. It is a city with a storied history, a city whose bronze walls have never been breached but it is no longer gloriously golden. Instead, it is a gilded turd, mired in filth, decaying, rotting, wilting and withering away.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">In Sorlost we follow Orhan Emmereth and the machinations, various plans, plots, politicking and scheming that he undertakes throughout the trilogy along with witnessing the fallout of his deceptions and lies.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">There are a few of other PoV characters in the trilogy but to avoid any spoilers on their story arcs and events from the trilogy I&#8217;ll refrain from mentioning them.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Marith is a drug addict (<em>Hatha</em>) and a drunk. A complicated character, conflicted and self-destructive. He is full of loathing and self-pity he hates himself and what he does but, at the same time, he likes doing what he does too, it gives him a sense of being, of purpose and like a coin he has two sides, two sides to his nature that war with each other. Along with moments of clarity, of lucidity, he spirals down into the throes of insanity and his fractured mind is a turbulent and churning sea. Heâ€™s captivating and heâ€™s someone that you love to hate.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Empires of Dust is populated by characters with hardly any morals or redeeming features. To give you an idea about him I&#8217;ve mentioned Marith in detail but honestly, I enjoyed reading about all the characters involved in the story that Smith Spark weaves over the three books.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The fighting in the Empires of Dust trilogy is plentiful, confusing and chaotic, violent, vivid and visceral.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The world-building is stellar and throughout the course of the trilogy the world opens up like a flower coming into bloom and Smith Sparks brings all of the locations to life thanks to her decadently descriptive writing. It is the small details that just add that little extra clarity, that makes the image, the location, the setting and the scene more evocative and more graphic.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Smith Spark has a very unique way of writing and writes with a mixture of richly detailed sentences that gently caress you with her words and short and snappy sentences that are sharp, harsh and like a bark. She often uses only a single word or a variety of words that all hold a similar meaning to convey emotion with both third-person perspective and first-person perspective thrown into the mix too.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">There is a beauty and a cadence to be found in Smith Sparkâ€™s lilting and lyrical writing. Her writing flows smoothly like blood from a freshly opened wound, like waves lapping on the shore and like leaves rustling on a gentle breeze. The mixture of sentences that are used to beat, bludgeon and pummel. Like chewing on broken glass, rusted nails and thorns. Then, the contrast, the counterpoint and those sentences that gently caress you, like a lovers hands, their soft touch, their warm embrace. Like soothing your mouth with the sweetest honey and quenching your thirst with a glass of ice-cold water.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Empires of Dust is the epitome of the beauty that can be found in darkness and grimdark at its finest. It is a tapestry of betrayal, blood, brutality, butchery, conquest, corpses, death, delusion, desires, destruction, killing, love, mania, machinations, pain, regrets, plots, politics, suffering, tragedy and violence.</span></p>
<h4 style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;">Of Blood and Bone by John Gwynne.</span></h4>

<ol>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>A Time of Dread</strong> (2018) &#8211; find my review </span><em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/03/13/a-time-of-dread-of-blood-and-bone-1-by-john-gwynne-bookreview-bookbloggers-bookblogger-blogger-fantasy/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>A Time of Blood</strong> (2019) &#8211; find my review</span> <em><strong><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2019/11/27/a-time-of-blood-of-blood-and-bone-2-by-john-gwynne-book-review-bookreview-bookblogger-bookbloggers-johngwynne-atimeofblood/">!!HERE!!</a></strong></em></li>
<li><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>A Time of Courage</strong> (2020) &#8211; find my review </span><strong><em><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2020/04/23/a-time-of-courage-of-blood-and-bone-3-by-john-gwynne-book-review/">!!HERE!!</a></em></strong></li>
</ol>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Taking place nearly one-hundred-and-fifty years after the Day of Wrath and the end The Faithful and the Fallen series (<em>my all-time favourite fantasy series</em>) the Of Blood and Bone trilogy is a stand-alone, self-contained and it firmly stands on its own as an outstanding trilogy. If you will, the Of Blood and Bone trilogy is a companion piece to The Faithful and the Fallen with the two mixing together like blood on a battlefield and telling a complete story.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">The Of Blood and Bone trilogy sees the continuation of the endless war between the Ben-Elim and the Kadoshim. On the surface it is a story about good vs evil but, it is so much more and there is a depth to the story and to the characters involved that transcends &#8216;<em>good vs evil</em>&#8216; and makes the story so much more.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">There is plenty of bloody, brutal, heart-pounding and visceral action in the Of Blood and Bone trilogy against a variety of foes and horrific fell creatures. The fight scenes are first-class, plentiful and written by Gwynne in stellar fashion and all engagement shave a heft to them, a weight to them that makes for edge-of-your-seat and exciting reading. Some are small scale and more personal with old scores to be settled whilst others are huge in scope with blockbuster sequences that are cinematic and consist of thousands of combatants upon the field. You easily picture yourself in the thick of the action, you feel the bone-crunching and jarring blows, the shouting of war cries, the screams of anguish and pain, the clash of swords, the thrum of bowstrings and the ground shaking with the impact and the wounds inflicted. You are there, not reading but, fighting alongside, transported, living and breathing the many battles.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Throughout your time spent reading the Of Blood and Bone trilogy, you will laugh, you will cry and you will care. You will go through a range of emotions from soaring highs to sorrowful lows. There will be moments where you fist-pump the air in joy and in relief. There are plentiful moments of dread and of fear for the fate of the characters where you curse Gwynne for the seemingly unending torment, torture and hell that he puts the characters through. As they struggle to endure, to survive against the odds and the overwhelming forces of evil and as they barely hang on against Asroth, the Kadoshim and the tides of darkness.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">There are the past and the present in the Of Blood and Bone trilogy with bygone names and events mentioned in revered tones. Legends that echo, that reverberate, that are laced with meaning and that, if you have read The Faithful and the Fallen series will have you nodding, smiling away at yourself and whispering the immortal battle cry of â€˜<em>Truth and Courage</em>â€˜. When you come to the end of A Time of Courage, the third and final book in the Of Blood and Bone trilogy new names will have been made, new legends will have been forged, risen to stand beside those of the past and who now have their own legend carved, etched and forever immortalised in the history of the Banished Lands.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Gwynne isnâ€™t afraid to get his hands dirty, bloody his axe, cleave bone, tear flesh and characters will die. During the trilogy, the characters endure many hardships and are put through the wringer time and time again. Will your favourites fall? Will they make it to the end? Itâ€™s not for me to say but, you are invested and eyes will water. You will mourn for the fallen and you will cheer for the living.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Thereâ€™s a strength to Gwynneâ€™s writing and a conviction that flows through his words as he concludes his powerfully told tale of good vs evil and he is a phenomenal storyteller. The story unfolds through multiple perspectives and the writing is descriptive, meaningful, emotive and often profound with weighted words and passages that are heavy with meaning. The characters all develop and grow throughout from the first few pages of A Time of Dread to the end of A Time o Courage they continue to develop. Gwynne doesnâ€™t just give you â€˜<em>characters</em>â€™ on a page, he gives you real people to root for, to cheer and the reverse, to hate and to vilify. There are many big loud and bombastic moments along with the intense action and ferocious fighting that takes place but, there is also plenty of room left for contemplation, for introspection, for quiet, retrospective and thoughtful moments too spread throughout the entire trilogy. There is also light to be found in the darkness with the banter and camaraderie that occurs between the characters. One thing with Gwynne, he writes animals so well, they arenâ€™t companions to the characters, they are characters in their own right and in the story, they are more, they are friend and warrior too.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Regardless of whether or not you have read The Faithful and the Fallen series you will still find a lot to like about the Of Blood and Bone trilogy&#8230;A LOT! For me, personally. I would say that I highly recommend reading The Faithful and the Fallen series first for the knowledge, added depth, shading to the world and the emotional impact that the names and events mentioned will have on you heightening your reading experience and elevating it to another richer level. If, however you do decide to dive straight into the Of Blood and Bone trilogy then I am that sure you will love it and I wish you many happy hours reading what is an incredible journey that Gwynne will take you on.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">For fantasy fans, Gwynne is a must-read author and a name that should be first on the lips of everyone when recommending a fantasy series/trilogy to another fantasy fan or, a reader looking to try fantasy.</span></p>
<p><span style="color:#000000;">Simply, the Of Blood and Bone trilogy is stunning and a masterpiece.</span></p>
<hr />
<p style="text-align:center;"><span style="color:#000000;"><strong>Follow The Tattooed Book Geek:</strong></span></p>

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I just finished up the Farseer trilogy earlier this year. It took me til book 3 to understand why everyone loves that series so much. I&#8217;m going to have to continue on with more Hobb.</p>
<p>Nice list!</p>

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-22850"><time datetime="2018-08-06T16:29:39+01:00">Aug 6, 2018 at 4:29 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I highly recommend you do. As it gets better.</p>
<p id="comment-like-22850" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=22850&#038;_wpnonce=0e8561d9d3" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-22850" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="2">2 people</a></span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-22849"><time datetime="2018-08-06T13:35:22+01:00">Aug 6, 2018 at 1:35 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Okay so my brother is obsessed with Robin Hobb so the Live Ship traders have been on my radar for a long time, but this has really convinced me to bump her up the list! I actually think live ships is such a cool idea, I&#8217;m kicking myself that I didn&#8217;t think of it first!<br />
I&#8217;ve got Prince Of Thorns on my bedside TBR because I do like grimdark, but I&#8217;m a bit nervous to begin it because of the reputation of just HOW dark Jorg is, as you say&#8230; I love fantasy characters who are rampant murderers (not sure what this says about me haha) but I can&#8217;t abide sexual violence against women in books because it strikes a little too close to the bone of real life society.</p>
<p id="comment-like-22849" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=22849&#038;_wpnonce=dff1eb6421" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-22849" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="1">1 person</a></span></p>

		<ol class="children">
		<li id="comment-22858" class="comment byuser comment-author-thetattooedbookgeek bypostauthor even depth-2">
			<article id="div-comment-22858" class="comment-body">
				<footer class="comment-meta">
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt='Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek&#039;s avatar' src='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G' srcset='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=90&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1.5x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=120&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 2x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=180&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 3x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=240&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 4x' class='avatar avatar-60' height='60' width='60' loading='lazy' decoding='async' />						<b class="fn"><a href="http://TheTattooedBookGeek.wordpress.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek</a></b> <span class="says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-22858"><time datetime="2018-08-06T18:30:05+01:00">Aug 6, 2018 at 6:30 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Jorg definitely is a crazy little psycho but such a fantastic character too. </p>
<p>Liveship&#8217;s is a fantastic idea. It sounds crazy ,absolutely crazy and I scoffed at reading it but damn, you care about ships which sounds crazy but it is so good. Definitely best to read Hobb in order though due to extra little bits you get in the books as the trilogies are all linked and take place in the same world.ðŸ‘ðŸ“š</p>
<p id="comment-like-22858" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=22858&#038;_wpnonce=eb764c4f7f" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-22858" class="comment-like-feedback">Like</span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/?replytocom=22858#respond" data-commentid="22858" data-postid="9876" data-belowelement="div-comment-22858" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek" aria-label="Reply to Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek">Reply</a></div>			</article><!-- .comment-body -->
		</li><!-- #comment-## -->

Stormlight archive and elantris are awesome too!</p>

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I read the first Mistborn book and overall I enjoyed it but also felt no need to carry on with the rest or try his other work. I might revisit him as an author again at some point in the future though.ðŸ‘ðŸ“š</p>
<p id="comment-like-46545" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=46545&#038;_wpnonce=8fb635e6f7" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-46545" class="comment-like-feedback">Like</span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Thank you &#8211; fantastic post!! Iâ€™ve read about half of these but havenâ€™t heard of some of them &#8211; definitely time to update my reading list, thanks!!</p>
<p id="comment-like-23727" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=23727&#038;_wpnonce=33a42dc7b2" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-23727" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="1">1 person</a></span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/?replytocom=23727#respond" data-commentid="23727" data-postid="9876" data-belowelement="div-comment-23727" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Lindsey" aria-label="Reply to Lindsey">Reply</a></div>			</article><!-- .comment-body -->
		</li><!-- #comment-## -->
		<li id="comment-23823" class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1 parent">
			<article id="div-comment-23823" class="comment-body">
				<footer class="comment-meta">
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt='Garrett Nicolai&#039;s avatar' src='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G' srcset='https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1x, https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=90&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1.5x, https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=120&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 2x, https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=180&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 3x, https://0.gravatar.com/avatar/c4004661106fbb326094c57b8c965e00a9d3e3245387f702c4375ae0c42d5341?s=240&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 4x' class='avatar avatar-60' height='60' width='60' loading='lazy' decoding='async' />						<b class="fn">Garrett Nicolai</b> <span class="says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-23823"><time datetime="2018-10-04T00:15:29+01:00">Oct 4, 2018 at 12:15 am</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I&#8217;ve been planning to read the Liveship series.  It&#8217;s been about five years since I read Farseer, and I remembered absolutely loving it, but wanted to do a re-read before returning to the Six Duchies.  I&#8217;ve been doing an audio re-read, and can&#8217;t recommend this series enough.  It&#8217;s fantastic.  Also, there are two further series in the &#8220;Realm of the Elderlings&#8221; beyond the Tawny Man series.  Have you read them?  If so, any comments?</p>
<p>Secondly, I can only take so much grimdark.  Any other recommendations that are a bit more light-hearted (not comedy, and not all the heroes have to survive, but I&#8217;d like something that doesn&#8217;t depress me quite as much as grimdark)?</p>
<p id="comment-like-23823" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=23823&#038;_wpnonce=a38a29087e" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-23823" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="1">1 person</a></span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<div class="reply"><a rel="nofollow" class="comment-reply-link" href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/?replytocom=23823#respond" data-commentid="23823" data-postid="9876" data-belowelement="div-comment-23823" data-respondelement="respond" data-replyto="Reply to Garrett Nicolai" aria-label="Reply to Garrett Nicolai">Reply</a></div>			</article><!-- .comment-body -->
		<ol class="children">
		<li id="comment-23829" class="comment byuser comment-author-thetattooedbookgeek bypostauthor even depth-2 parent">
			<article id="div-comment-23829" class="comment-body">
				<footer class="comment-meta">
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt='Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek&#039;s avatar' src='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G' srcset='https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=60&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=90&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 1.5x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=120&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 2x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=180&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 3x, https://2.gravatar.com/avatar/b2dd8fa88bc554fd6550222666a8ab2a2f25b0030a653e64ac92c5c4e9e4622d?s=240&#038;d=monsterid&#038;r=G 4x' class='avatar avatar-60' height='60' width='60' loading='lazy' decoding='async' />						<b class="fn"><a href="http://TheTattooedBookGeek.wordpress.com" class="url" rel="ugc">Drew @ The Tattooed Book Geek</a></b> <span class="says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-23829"><time datetime="2018-10-04T05:49:49+01:00">Oct 4, 2018 at 5:49 am</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I&#8217;ve read The Rainwild Chronicles series by Hobb. I&#8217;d have perhaps included it in the list but it&#8217;s not a trilogy and whilst enjoyable and good it wasn&#8217;t as good, for me, as Farseer, Liveship and Tawny Man. It ties in with them all though and is enjoyable and is also less dark too. </p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t read the other trilogy completely yet. The first book is decent but slow and the second one is fantastic but once I read the third it&#8217;s over so I&#8217;ve been putting it off.</p>
<p>I can&#8217;t think of any other trilogies. Sorry, there&#8217;s lots out there but I tend towards the darker grimdark stuff and only started reading fantasy in 2011 and I&#8217;m a slow reader too so miss out on many myself.</p>
<p id="comment-like-23829" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=23829&#038;_wpnonce=050b5462e6" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-23829" class="comment-like-feedback">Like</span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Thanks,</p>
<p>It&#8217;s not that I completely avoid grimdark; it&#8217;s just that I&#8217;d appreciate good series that are not so focused on showing the darker sides of humanity.  </p>
<p>Thanks for the comments on the further Elderling series.  After I finish my reread, I&#8217;ll be moving into the Liveship series, but probably won&#8217;t get to Tawny man for a few years anyway.  This list gives me some other alternatives, as well.  They are appreciated.</p>

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I love Robin Hobbs!</p>

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-44446"><time datetime="2019-09-05T17:10:40+01:00">Sep 5, 2019 at 5:10 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I just returned to the Realm of the Elderlings recently, and am 2/3rds through Liveship Traders.  It really is wonderful.  And it&#8217;s not really about &#8220;talking ships&#8221; any more than the Two Towers is about &#8220;talking trees&#8221;.  They are a significant part of the story, but have a great (and tragic) story behind them, just as the Ents do.</p>
<p id="comment-like-44446" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=44446&#038;_wpnonce=07233aaa66" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-44446" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="1">1 person</a></span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-44863"><time datetime="2019-10-06T12:47:24+01:00">Oct 6, 2019 at 12:47 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Hahahaha&#8230;. the first 9 and the last series is everything on my TBR&#8230; stop living in my head. The funny thing, randomly, is that up until like a month ago, I had no idea who Mark Lawrence was. A internet friend of mine who loves him (we&#8217;ve talked since my days of blogging hockey) and was bemoaning the ending of his last series and mentioned the start of his next series. So I went on Edelweiss to see if I could get him information on when it would start and the name. I noticed the imprint putting it out and emailed them and they said they&#8217;d send me a copy when  it was available. Kevin flipped his lid. Because apparently this guy is like mega huge. I didn&#8217;t know lol. I just figured I&#8217;d ask? Anyhow that is my completely long winded story of how I found out about Mark Lawrence and apparently have been listed for a coveted ARC that I didn&#8217;t know about.</p>

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Glad you included Robin Hobb&#8217;s trilogy of trilogies, as they&#8217;re really not complete on their own. ðŸ™‚</p>
<p>Nice to see Chronicles of the Unhewn Throne there, it doesn&#8217;t get nearly the love it deserves.</p>

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Of course, all three are brilliant and all tie in together.ðŸ‘ I&#8217;d probably have her other trilogy on the list too but I&#8217;ve never gotten around to reading the final book. </p>

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Left out:<br />
The Rebel of the Sands series by Alwyn Hamilton<br />
The Goblin Series by Jaq D. Hawkins<br />
The Lightbringer series by Brent Weeks<br />
The Rivers of London series by Ben Aaronovitch</p>

					<p>Good list, but yes, needs some Brandon Sanderson in the mix! Mistborn is incredible!!!</p>
<p id="comment-like-48944" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=48944&#038;_wpnonce=b77f2ed9e6" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-48944" class="comment-like-feedback">Liked by <a href="#" class="view-likers" data-like-count="1">1 person</a></span></p>
				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<footer class="comment-meta">

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-48945"><time datetime="2020-09-12T21:05:38+01:00">Sep 12, 2020 at 9:05 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I&#8217;m not a Sanderson fan, I read and enjoyed the first Mistborn book, but never felt the want or need to carry on with the series and I haven&#8217;t read any of his other stuff either. </p>
<p id="comment-like-48945" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=48945&#038;_wpnonce=6a740bac9c" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-48945" class="comment-like-feedback">Like</span></p>

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>Have never been able to get into Brandon Sanderson&#8217;s books and have tried so many times! Yet, I loved the way he finished the Wheel of Time series</p>
<p id="comment-like-58567" data-liked=comment-not-liked class="comment-likes comment-not-liked"><a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/?like_comment=58567&#038;_wpnonce=20a97d8a0e" class="comment-like-link needs-login" rel="nofollow" data-blog="107964151"><span>Like</span></a><span id="comment-like-count-58567" class="comment-like-feedback">Like</span></p>

				<footer class="comment-meta">
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img referrerpolicy="no-referrer" alt='Beverley Burgess Bell&#039;s avatar' src='https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large' srcset='https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large 1x, https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large 1.5x, https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large 2x, https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large 3x, https://graph.facebook.com/v6.0/1136234301/picture?type=large 4x' class='avatar avatar-60' height='60' width='60' loading='lazy' decoding='async' />						<b class="fn">Beverley Burgess Bell</b> <span class="says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://thetattooedbookgeek.wordpress.com/2018/08/06/top-finished-fantasy-trilogies-you-should-read/comment-page-2/#comment-58566"><time datetime="2022-12-08T15:02:15+00:00">Dec 8, 2022 at 3:02 pm</time></a>					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

									</footer><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content">
					<p>I&#8217;m so glad I came upon this post. Was in despair at having nothing interesting to read. But have started Prince of Thorns and am hooked even as I&#8217;m shocked at what a 13-year-old boy can do, think or feel! Think I&#8217;m going to enjoy this series. And it&#8217;s long &#8211; yay! Looking forward to reading all the books.</p>

</form><script type="text/javascript">
/* <![CDATA[ */

( ( dropdownId ) => {
	const dropdown = document.getElementById( dropdownId );
	function onSelectChange() {
		setTimeout( () => {
			if ( 'escape' === dropdown.dataset.lastkey ) {
				return;
			}
			if ( dropdown.value && parseInt( dropdown.value ) > 0 && dropdown instanceof HTMLSelectElement ) {
				dropdown.parentElement.submit();
			}
		}, 250 );
	}
	function onKeyUp( event ) {
		if ( 'Escape' === event.key ) {
			dropdown.dataset.lastkey = 'escape';
		} else {
			delete dropdown.dataset.lastkey;
		}
	}
	function onClick() {
		delete dropdown.dataset.lastkey;
	}
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'keyup', onKeyUp );
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'click', onClick );
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'change', onSelectChange );
})( "cat" );

//# sourceURL=WP_Widget_Categories%3A%3Awidget
/* ]]> */
</script>

			<script type="text/javascript">
/* <![CDATA[ */

( ( dropdownId ) => {
	const dropdown = document.getElementById( dropdownId );
	function onSelectChange() {
		setTimeout( () => {
			if ( 'escape' === dropdown.dataset.lastkey ) {
				return;
			}
			if ( dropdown.value ) {
				document.location.href = dropdown.value;
			}
		}, 250 );
	}
	function onKeyUp( event ) {
		if ( 'Escape' === event.key ) {
			dropdown.dataset.lastkey = 'escape';
		} else {
			delete dropdown.dataset.lastkey;
		}
	}
	function onClick() {
		delete dropdown.dataset.lastkey;
	}
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'keyup', onKeyUp );
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'click', onClick );
	dropdown.addEventListener( 'change', onSelectChange );
})( "archives-dropdown-5" );

//# sourceURL=WP_Widget_Archives%3A%3Awidget
/* ]]> */
</script>

<script type="text/javascript" src="//0.gravatar.com/js/hovercards/hovercards.min.js?ver=202601924dcd77a86c6f1d3698ec27fc5da92b28585ddad3ee636c0397cf312193b2a1" id="grofiles-cards-js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" id="wpgroho-js-extra">
/* <![CDATA[ */
var WPGroHo = {"my_hash":""};

<script crossorigin='anonymous' type='text/javascript'  src='/wp-content/mu-plugins/gravatar-hovercards/wpgroho.js?m=1610363240i'></script>

	<script>
		// Initialize and attach hovercards to all gravatars
		( function() {
			function init() {
				if ( typeof Gravatar === 'undefined' ) {
					return;
				}

				if ( typeof Gravatar.init !== 'function' ) {
					return;
				}

				Gravatar.profile_cb = function ( hash, id ) {
					WPGroHo.syncProfileData( hash, id );
				};

				Gravatar.my_hash = WPGroHo.my_hash;
				Gravatar.init(
					'body',
					'#wp-admin-bar-my-account',
					{
						i18n: {
							'Edit your profile â†’': 'Edit your profile â†’',
							'View profile â†’': 'View profile â†’',
							'Contact': 'Contact',
							'Send money': 'Send money',
							'Sorry, we are unable to load this Gravatar profile.': 'Sorry, we are unable to load this Gravatar profile.',

				);
			}

			if ( document.readyState !== 'loading' ) {
				init();
			} else {
				document.addEventListener( 'DOMContentLoaded', init );
			}
		} )();
	</script>

		<div style="display:none">
	<div class="grofile-hash-map-a375c2ccfad7c9ecc77a16c433150b66">
	</div>
